molecular.simulations.ExchangeHistory¶

class molecular.simulations.ExchangeHistory(data, only_neighbors=True)[source]¶

Replica-exchange and other coupled Markov chain simulations follow replicas over time as they walk across configuration space. Here, “configuration” is used generically and can refer to temperature (commonly), Hamiltonian scaling factors, etc.

The purpose of this class is to permit easy evaluation of exchange performance. We can compute (and plot) parameters like the exchange rate, mosaic plot of the replica walk, the Hansmann parameter, and tunneling time.

Methods:

__init__(data, only_neighbors=True)[source]¶

data must be a pandas DataFrame with the columns “replica”, “config”, and “step”. Note that the elements in “replica” and “config” refer to indices.

Parameters

  • data (pandas.DataFrame) – Exchange history.

  • only_neighbors (bool) – Were exchanges permitted only between neighbors?

crosstab(index='config', column='replica')[source]¶

Cross-tabulate by “config” and “replica” axes. In other words, count the number of snapshots at given config and replica indices.

Parameters

  • index (str) – Axis to define rows.

  • column (str) – Axis to define columns.

Returns

Cross-tabulation of the ExchangeHistory instance.

Return type

pandas.DataFrame

exchange_rate(by='config', n_attempts=None, terminal_factor=0.5)[source]¶

Compute the exchange rate.

Parameters

  • by (str) – Default: config

  • n_attempts (int) – Number of attempts per config or replica.

  • terminal_factor (float) – Factor to apply to the first and last config to reduce its number of attempts.

Returns

Exchange rate per config or replica.

Return type

pandas.Series

classmethod from_namd(fname, n_replicas, glob=False)[source]¶

Construct the exchange history from the results of NAMD replica exchange.

Parameters

  • fname (str) – Name of the history file. The assumption is that there is one history file per replica. This method expects to find the variable {replica} to specify the file for each replica.

  • n_replicas (int) – The number of replicas.

  • glob (bool) – Indicates if fname contains extra glob-like features, such as wild-cards.

Returns

Newly-created instance of ExchangeHistory.

Return type

ExchangeHistory

Examples

>>> ExchangeHistory.from_namd('exchange_{replica}.history', n_replicas=16, glob=False)
>>> ExchangeHistory.from_namd('exchange_job?.{replica}.history', n_replicas=16, glob=True)
classmethod from_parquet(fname)[source]¶

Read exchange history from parquet.

Parameters

fname (str) – Parquet file.

Returns

Return type

ExchangeHistory

hansmann()[source]¶

The Hansmann parameter \(h(T)\) shows the residence time \(\tau\) replica \(r\) (of \(R\) total replicas) spends at configuration \(T\).

\[h(T) = 1 - \frac{\sqrt{\sum_{r=1}^R \tau_r^2}}{\sum_{r=1}^R \tau_r}\]

If all replicas are equally sampled across all configurations, then \(h(T) = 1 - 1 / \sqrt{R}\).

Returns

Hansmann parameter computed for all configurations.

Return type

pandas.Series

hansmann_plot(x_title=None, y_title=None, plot_theoretical=True)[source]¶

Parameters

  • y_title (str) –

  • plot_theoretical (bool) – Should the theoretical Hansmann parameter in the case of equal sampling be plotted? (Default: True)

mosaic_plot(interval=100, cmap='ujet')[source]¶

Plot the mosaic function using a heatmap.

Parameters

  • interval (int) – Interval for plotting. We usually cannot plot every single step because there is too much data.

  • cmap (str or object) – The matplotlib-compatible color map.

reset_step()[source]¶

Resets step from arbitrary interval to rank from 1 … N. This operation occurs in place.

Save ExchangeHistory to csv format. Follows pandas.DataFrame.to_csv.
